text:
Emotional intelligence is about:

1. The ability to know what you’re feeling and how it’s affecting you
2. The ability to apply your emotions to tasks like thinking and problem-solving
3. Managing your emotions well and helping others do the same
So, you'd ask questions around each of those. (E.g., Can you tell me about a time you failed at something and how that felt?). People are trained to say "I see failure as a learning opportunity" but they're not trained to share how they processed their emotions.

And yes, I would do a skills-based test ... probably around the one thing that's hardest to teach. For me, that's content strategy. So maybe give them a sample business strategy and a sample content strategy and ask them to provide strategic recommendations about how to improve it. That way you're seeing how well they deliver feedback/manage up PLUS gauge their marketing acumen.

text: (A super helpful contribution, I know..) But for real, it's a real challenge to unload projects that you were personally in charge of and have someone take over the reins. I personally feel like you can test them all day long, but you are not going to know how they work out until they are sitting in the driver's seat and fully immersed into your companies culture. A lot of the responsibilities you have outlined are content-based, but the candidate needs to be social, charismatic, and able to....well, herd cats. As a freelancer some of my best clients are the managers who know the content inside and out, are friendly, approachable and understand both people and the content. I feel like the content is the easy part - it's finding someone who can  organize and manage people that is always a challenge!

text: You could ask what kind of agenda they like to follow for one-on-ones, what they ask, and why.  You could also ask them how they know if they're veering too far toward micromanaging, or if they're veering too far in the other direction.  I think striking this balance is uniquely important in a situation where you're making yourself a skip-level for former reports.  You can feel out whether their style is compatible with yours, which will tell you how jarring or smooth it might be for the existing team.  And, on the recon side, once you'd narrowed down the existing pool of folks, you might take a look at where they'd run a program like this before, and see if you can determine the rate of turnover among contributors in that program.
